revision.text:
{{Infobox animanga/Header | name = Air | image = Air original game cover.jpg | imagesize = 275px | caption = ''Air'' original visual novel cover. Depicted are Kano (left), Misuzu (center), and Minagi (right). | genre = [[Drama]], [[fantasy]], [[Romance novel|romance]] }} {{Infobox animanga/Game | developer = [[Key (company)|Key]] | publisher = [[VisualArt's]] (Windows)
[[Interchannel|NEC Interchannel]] (DC, PS2)
[[Prototype (company)|Prototype]] (SoftBank 3G, PSP, FOMA) | genre = [[Eroge]], [[Visual novel]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Dreamcast]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[SoftBank Mobile]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Freedom of Mobile Multimedia Access|FOMA]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]], [[PlayStation Vita]] | released = {{vgrelease|JP|September 8, 2000}} }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = [[Key (company)|Key]] | illustrator = [[Yukimaru Katsura]] | publisher = [[Kadokawa Shoten]] | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | magazine = [[Comptiq]] | first = August 10, 2004 | last = February 10, 2006 | volumes = 2 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | director = [[Tatsuya Ishihara]] | writer = [[Fumihiko Shimo]] | music = {{flatlist| *[[Jun Maeda]] *[[Shinji Orito]] *[[Magome Togoshi]] }} | studio = [[Kyoto Animation]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee | AUS = [[Madman Entertainment]] | NA = [[Funimation]] }} | network = [[BS-TBS|BS-i]] | network_en = {{English anime networks | US = [[Anime Network]] }} | first = January 6, 2005 | last = March 31, 2005 | episodes = 13 | episode_list = List of Air episodes#Air }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | title = Air in Summer | director = [[Tatsuya Ishihara]] | writer = [[Fumihiko Shimo]] | music = {{flatlist| *[[Jun Maeda]] *[[Shinji Orito]] *[[Magome Togoshi]] }} | studio = [[Kyoto Animation]] | licensee = {{English anime licensee | AUS = [[Madman Entertainment]] | NA = [[Funimation]] }} | network = BS-i | first = August 28, 2005 | last = September 4, 2005 | episodes = 2 | episode_list = List of Air episodes#Air in Summer }} {{Infobox animanga/Other | title = Other | content = *[[Air (2005 film)|''Air'' film]] }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} '''''Air''''' is a Japanese [[Eroge|adult]] [[visual novel]] developed by [[Key (company)|Key]] released on September 8, 2000 for [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] [[Personal computers|PCs]]. Key later released versions of ''Air'' without the erotic content, and the game was [[Porting|ported]] to the [[Dreamcast]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[PlayStation Portable]] and [[PlayStation Vita]]. The story follows the life of Yukito Kunisaki, a traveling [[showman]] searching for the "girl in the sky". He arrives in a quiet, seaside town where he meets three girls, one of whom is the key to the end of his journey. The [[gameplay]] in ''Air'' follows a [[Nonlinear gameplay#Branching storylines|branching plot line]] which offers pre-determined scenarios with courses of interaction, and focuses on the appeal of the three female main characters by the [[player character]]. The game is divided into three segments—Dream, Summer, and Air—which serve as different phases in the overall story. The title of the game reflects the prominent themes of the air, skies, and use of wings throughout gameplay. The game ranked as the best-selling PC game sold in Japan for the time of its release, and charted in the national top 50 several more times afterwards. ''Air'' has sold over 300,000 units across several platforms. Following the game's release, ''Air'' made several transitions into other media. A [[manga]] by [[Yukimaru Katsura]] was serialized in [[Kadokawa Shoten]]'s ''[[Comptiq]]'', and later published into two volumes. [[Comic anthology|Comic anthologies]] and [[art book]]s were also published, as were [[audio drama]]s and several albums of music. [[Kyoto Animation]] produced a 13-episode [[anime]] television series and a two-episode anime mini-series in 2005, and [[Toei Animation]] produced an anime film in 2005. The anime adaptations are licensed by [[Funimation]] who released them in North America. ==Gameplay== [[File:Misuzu original Air game.jpg|left|200px|thumb|Typical dialogue and narrative in ''Air'' depicting the main character Yukito talking to Misuzu.]] ''Air'' is a [[Romance (love)|romance]] [[visual novel]] in which the player assumes the role of three characters.{{Cite book|publication-date=April 2001|title=Air art works|publisher=[[Paradigm (publisher)|Paradigm]]|page=224|isbn=978-4-89490-318-0}} Much of its [[gameplay]] is spent on reading the story's [[narrative]] and [[dialogue]]. ''Air'' follows a [[Nonlinear gameplay#Branching storylines|branching plot line]] with multiple endings, and depending on the decisions that the player makes during the game, the plot will progress in a specific direction. With the consumer ports, if an undesired choice was selected, there would be an option to rewind the story to correct the mistake. However, if the player reaches a bad end to a storyline, the player does not have this option and must reload the game at the last saved point. There are five main plot lines that the player will have the chance to experience, three which are initially available and two more which can later become available. Throughout gameplay, the player is given multiple options to choose from, and text progression pauses at these points until a choice is made. To view all plot lines in their entirety, the player will have to replay the game multiple times and choose different choices to further the plot to an alternate direction. When first playing the game, the player assumes the role of Yukito Kunisaki and the scenarios for the three heroines are available in what is called the Dream [[story arc]]. After the plot lines for these three heroines have been completed, an additional scenario called Summer is made available where the player assumes the role of Ryūya. Summer is a linear novel arc in which no choices are presented to the player.{{cite web|url= http://brightbell.main.jp/kipima/game/Air/Summer.html|title=Summer arc playthrough chart|accessdate=May 16, 2008|language=Japanese}} Upon the completion of the Summer route, another scenario called Air is made available, which serves as the true ending to the story. In Air, the player assumes the role of a [[Jungle Crow|crow]] named Sora. In the [[Hentai|adult]] versions of the game, there are scenes with sexual [[Computer graphics|CGs]] depicting Yukito and a given heroine having sex. Later, Key released versions of ''Air'' without the erotic content. ==Plot== [[File:Air town.png|thumb|200px|left|''Air'' takes place in a town modeled on Kami, Japan.]] ===Setting and themes=== There are important locations featured in ''Air'' that are based on places in the city [[Kami, Hyōgo (Mikata)|Kami]] in [[Hyōgo Prefecture]], Japan. ''Air'' is set in the [[Kasumi, Hyogo|Kasumi]] district of Kami; during the course of the series' creation, Kasumi was an individual town that has since merged with two others to form the city of Kami. Many of the locales in ''Air'', such as the [[seawall]], the [[train station]], the [[Jinja (Shinto)|shrine]], and the school are based on real places.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070302103022/http://htc.moon.st/ota/05041601.html|url=http://htc.moon.st/ota/05041601.html|archivedate=March 2, 2007|title=Air's setting based on real locations|publisher=htc.moon.st|accessdate=June 8, 2009|language=Japanese}} As ''Air'' is set in the middle of summer, the season offers bright, sunny skies for the town during the day.'''Untranslated quote:''' その先には閉ざすものなく、空が広がっていた。遮へい物のひとつもない。陽光が揺らいだ。
'''Translated quote:''' "In front of me is an unchecked, wide open sky. No obscuring objects whatsoever. The sunlight oscillated down."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} In the manga adaptation, the town is described as a "quiet town with few people...with nothing but beaches and countryside."{{cite book|last=Katsura|first=Yukimaru|title=Air manga volume 1|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|year= 2004|page=153}} Scenario assistant [[Yūichi Suzumoto]] has commented that his impression of ''Air'' is similar to that of a [[folk song]] due to the rural setting and heartwarming story progression. As indicated by the title, air, skies and wings are important themes: Yukito is searching for the "girl in the sky", and Misuzu believes that her other self is flying in the sky above her. Other characters show a similar relationship to the sky, such as Minagi who is a member of the [[astronomy]] club,'''Untranslated quote:''' …部活動というものがあるのです…天文部です
'''Translated quote:''' "...There's still club activities...the astronomy club."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} and Michiru who has a fondness for [[Soap bubble|bubbles]] that float in the air. Kano wants wings to fly, and Kanna already has them. Misuzu names a crow she finds {{Nihongo|''Sora''|空|}}—Japanese for "sky". Another major theme is the [[maternal bond]], as the four heroines' stories, as well as Yukito's, revolve around their mothers, either biological or adoptive. Main scenario writer [[Jun Maeda]] commented that he prefers to include mothers in games if given the choice between only including a mother or a father, as is what happened with ''Air'', though he backs this up by noting that in [[bishōjo game]]s, women are the main focus anyway. Complicated relationships involving family members and friends play a key part throughout the story. One of the sub-themes in the story is [[magic (paranormal)|magic]].'''Untranslated quote:''' 魔法が使えたらって、思ったことないかなぁ？
'''Translated quote:''' "If you could use sorcery, what do you think would happen?"
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} Uraha, Yukito's mother,'''Untranslated quote:''' 俺が母親から伝えられた、手を触れずに人形を操る力。
'''Translated quote:''' "I had inherited the ability to control puppets without touching them from my mother."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} and Yukito himself'''Untranslated quote:''' 手を触れることなく、人形を動かす力。俺にとっては当たり前の力。この少女にわかる言葉で、それを説明するなら…「…一種の魔法だ」
'''Translated quote:''' A power that can move a puppet without touching it. To me, it's a power that's nothing out of the ordinary. But if I had to explain it to this girl using terminology she knew... "...it's a kind of magic."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} have the ability to use magic, though Yukito is the least skilled among them. Kano was told by her sister that when she grows up and takes off her yellow ribbon, she will gain the power to do magic. However, the problems of parents leaving their offspring and poverty are displayed realistically. ===Main characters=== {| style="font-size:100%; float:right; width:33em; margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em; background:transparent;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" |- ! style="font-size:100%; padding-left:0em;" | Cast |- | {| class="infobox wikitable" style="width:100%; margin:0;" cellpadding="3" |- ! width="30%"| Role ! Japanese voice actor{{cite web|author=Amith, Dennis|url=http://j-entonline.com/blu-ray-dvd-reviews/dvd-reviews-film-tv/anime-reviews/air-the-complete-series-a-j-ent-anime-dvd-review/|title=AIR – The Complete Series (a J!-ENT Anime DVD Review)|publisher=J!-ENT|date=May 16, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2017}} ! English voice actor |- |Yukito Kunisaki{{Nihongo4||国崎 往人|Kunisaki Yukito}} |[[Hikaru Midorikawa]] (game, film)
[[Daisuke Ono]] (anime series) |[[Vic Mignogna]] |- |Misuzu Kamio{{Nihongo4||神尾 観鈴|Kamio Misuzu}} |[[Tomoko Kawakami]] |[[Monica Rial]] |- |Kano Kirishima{{Nihongo4||霧島 佳乃|Kirishima Kano}} |Asami Okamoto |[[Stephanie Wittels]] |- |Minagi Tohno{{Nihongo4||遠野 美凪|Tōno Minagi}} |[[Ryoka Yuzuki]] |[[Kira Vincent-Davis]] |- |Haruko Kamio{{Nihongo4||神尾 晴子|Kamio Haruko}} |[[Aya Hisakawa]] |[[Luci Christian]] |- |Hijiri Kirishima{{Nihongo4||霧島 聖|Kirishima Hijiri}} |[[Yumi Tōma]] |[[Christine Auten]] |- |Michiru{{Nihongo4||みちる}} |[[Yukari Tamura]] |[[Serena Varghese]] |- |Kanna{{Nihongo4||神奈}} |[[Chinami Nishimura]] |Cynthia Martinez |- |Ryūya{{Nihongo4||柳也}} |[[Nobutoshi Canna]] |[[Jay Hickman (actor)|Jay Hickman]] |- |Uraha{{Nihongo4||裏葉}} |[[Kikuko Inoue]] |[[Allison Sumrall]] |- |Potato{{Nihongo4||ポテト|Poteto}} |[[Hiromi Konno]] |[[Tiffany Grant]] |} |} The player assumes the role of Yukito Kunisaki, the protagonist of ''Air''. He lives a poor life going from town to town with little money, trying to make a living off his show with a puppet. By being an adolescent or young adult, Yukito sometimes acts childishly if provoked. Yukito tends to be helpful to those around him while trying to earn any money at the same time, and does his best to look after Misuzu in the Dream arc. Misuzu Kamio, the main heroine of ''Air'', makes Yukito quite mistrustful at first by being too friendly, but eventually earns his affection. She is a cheerful but introverted, slightly clumsy and simplistic high school girl, and often utters the pseudo-dinosauric phrase ''gao'' when she feels troubled, a habit she retained from childhood. Misuzu has a great love of [[dinosaur]]s, finding the story of their glory and extinction "romantic". As a child, her fascination with dinosaurs stemmed from thinking chicks would grow into them; her adoptive mother Haruko Kamio thinks it is ridiculous. The second of the three heroines Yukito meets after Misuzu is Kano Kirishima, a girl attending the same school as Misuzu. She is usually energetic, playful, and tells jokes by saying nonsensical things. Kano is friends with a strange stray dog named Potato that follows her around and is able to communicate in his strange manner of speech.'''Untranslated quote:''' 見事にコミュニケーションがなされている。
'''Translated quote:''' "She surprisingly seems to be able to communicate with it."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} Kano still believes in things she was told by her older sister Hijiri as a child as a way of coping with her past. The third and final heroine Yukito meets is a girl in Misuzu's class at school named Minagi Tohno, a top student in the school who is introverted as well. Until she met Yukito, her only friend was Michiru, with whom she often blows bubbles at the abandoned train station in town. ===Story=== ''Air''{{'s}} story revolves around three girls whose lives are connected to the same man. In the first [[story arc]], Dream, Yukito Kunisaki is a [[showman]] traveling across Japan, continuing his late mother's search for the "girl in the sky".'''Untranslated quote:''' …この空の向こうには、翼を持った少女がいる。…それは、ずっと昔から。…そして、今、この時も。それは俺が幼い頃、母に聞かされた言葉だった。詳しいことを教えるより先に、母は死んでしまった。それ以来、俺は一人で旅を続けてきた。空にいる少女の話。
'''Translated quote:''' "...at the far end of the sky, there is a girl who has wings...from the distant past...even now, she is still there. That is what I heard from my mother when I was small. Before I could ask more clearly, my mother died. After that, I continued journeying alone. The myth of the girl in the sky."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} The story opens on Monday July 17, 2000 when Yukito comes across a small seaside town where the story takes place. On his first day in town, Yukito tries to earn money by putting on a mysterious puppet show where he manipulates a doll magically without strings for a small audience of kids passing by. Yukito is unsuccessful in gaining the children's favor, and the children leave without paying him for his performance. That night, Yukito sleeps on the town's [[seawall]] by the beach. Yukito collapses from [[heat stroke]] the next day and is taken to a nearby fisherman's guild; after he awakens, they feed him, and give him some very large rice balls to take with him as he is leaving. As he sits on the town's seawall eating one of the rice balls, he notices a young girl beside him who introduces herself as Misuzu Kamio—a sincere yet clumsy girl who is eager to become friends with him. Misuzu persistently attempts to play with him, while Yukito tries to refuse her efforts. He eventually follows her home lured by the chance to eat. After Haruko, Misuzu's aunt and foster mother, is persuaded, it is decided that he will stay with them for the time being.'''Untranslated quote:''' …わかった。泊めたる。納屋にな。
'''Translated quote:''' "...I understand. Stay here. Sleep in the garage."
{{cite video game| title = Air| developer = [[Key (company)|Key]]| publisher = [[VisualArt's]]| date=September 8, 2000| language = Japanese}} The next day, Yukito meets a girl named Kano Kirishima and a stray dog named Potato; Kano and Misuzu go to the same high school. Later that day, Yukito meets a third girl named Minagi Tohno, Misuzu's classmate, and her friend Michiru. Like Misuzu, both Kano and Minagi have strange personalities connected with mysterious pasts. Before long, a legend of "one thousand summers" begins to unfold where the mysteries of the past are framed primarily by the relationship between Yukito and Misuzu. The cursed "girl in the sky" Yukito has been searching for turns out to be Misuzu. By the time he figures this out, she has already grown to love him and has passed her 15th birthday. Once these things have come to pass, the "girl in the sky" is cursed to die. The remainder of this arc is dedicated to Yukito's attempt to save her, trying to effectively break the curse. The next arc, Summer, reveals events that occurred in the summer of one thousand years before the Dream arc, taking place in the [[Heian period]].The Dream and Air arcs in ''Air'' are set in 2000; one thousand years prior in Japan in 1000 was during the [[Heian period]].{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://search.eb.com/eb/article-9039814|title=Heian period|encyclopedia= [[Encyclopædia Britannica]]|year=2008|accessdate=May 16, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080511040345/http://search.eb.com/eb/article-9039814| archivedate= 11 May 2008 | deadurl= no}} Kannabi no mikoto, or Kanna, is one of the last winged beings in ''Air''{{'}}s fictional setting and is held as a prisoner in her own castle. Since she bears wings on her back, she is not permitted to leave the castle walls or see her mother, who is in a similar situation elsewhere. With Ryūya, a member of her [[samurai]] guard, and Uraha, a fledgling telekinetic, Kanna escapes and traverses feudal Japan to find her mother. However, the rest of the guard and a sect of [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[monk]]s follow them. After catching up, they place a curse on Kanna where she must endure constant reincarnation and death whenever she finds love; Misuzu is one such reincarnation. In the last arc, Air, Yukito's final wish to save Misuzu's life is heard. The timeline of the Dream arc has been reset, although it is now seen through the viewpoint of a crow Misuzu finds and names Sora. New things are revealed that were not seen following Yukito in the Dream arc. After Misuzu finds Sora and brings him back home, her condition worsens and eventually she forgets even who Haruko is. Misuzu's father, Keisuke Tachibana, shows up during this arc wanting to take Misuzu back to his home, but Haruko pleads with him to grant her more time, and they agree on extending the time for three more days. After the three days pass, Keisuke comes back and sees the love between Misuzu and Haruko; he decides to let them stay together. The remainder of this arc has Misuzu and Haruko spending time together like mother and daughter, culminating in Misuzu's death. ==Development== After the completion of ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'', the Key staff started production on ''Air'' and expanded the number of people involved in this project compared to ''Kanon''. The [[executive producer]] for ''Air'' was Takahiro Baba from [[VisualArt's]], the publishing company that Key is under. The planning for ''Air'' was headed by [[Jun Maeda]] who was also one of two main scenario writers, the other being Takashi Ishikawa.{{cite web|url=http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=84|title=''Air'' staff information|publisher=Erogamescape|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001020927/http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=84|archivedate=October 1, 2007| accessdate=December 19, 2014|language=Japanese}} Scenario assistance was provided by four more people: Kazuki Fujii, Kai, Tōya Okano, and [[Yūichi Suzumoto]]. Art direction was headed by Key's artist [[Itaru Hinoue]] who worked on the character design. Further computer graphics were split between three people—Miracle Mikipon, [[Na-Ga]], and Shinory—and background art was provided by Din and Torino. The music in the game was [[composer|composed]] primarily by [[Shinji Orito]], Jun Maeda, and [[Magome Togoshi]], who had started working with Key since before ''Kanon''{{'}}s release. After the completion of ''Air'', two of the staff—Kazuki Fujii, and Takashi Ishikawa—left Key.{{cite web|url=http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=3454 |title=''Clannad'' staff information |publisher=Erogamescape |accessdate=June 8, 2007 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513014844/http://erogamescape.ddo.jp/~ap2/ero/toukei_kaiseki/game.php?game=3454 |archivedate=13 May 2007 |deadurl=yes }} [[Jun Maeda]], the main scenario writer of ''Air'', commented that in the early stages of ''Air''{{'s}} production, it was already decided that it was to be an [[Eroge|adult game]], and he further assumes that if it was not at least first released with adult content, that it would not have been as commercially successful. Maeda also commented that he wanted to write ''Air'' to give players the chance to experience the entire story as a whole rather than just a sum of differing parts as typical [[bishōjo game]]s do, including ''Kanon''. While attempting to do this, Maeda also tried to simultaneously make it seem similar to typical visual novels in the same genre as ''Air'' to give the game appeal to the players who often play such games. As such, while the game incorporates stories from several characters, they are all of varying lengths.{{cite web|url=http://akirunoneko.at.infoseek.co.jp/archive/text/AIR_interview.htm |title=Key Scenario Staff Long Interview |publisher=Colorful Pure Girl |date=March 2001 |accessdate=May 16, 2008 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605054025/http://akirunoneko.at.infoseek.co.jp/archive/text/AIR_interview.htm |archivedate=5 June 2008 |deadurl=yes }} ===Release history=== ''Air'' was released as an adult game on September 8, 2000 as a limited edition, playable on a [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] [[Personal computers|PC]] as a 2-disc [[CD-ROM]] set.{{cite web|url=http://www.product.co.jp/products/item/154/|title=Air 初回限定版|trans-title=Air limited edition|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|accessdate=December 19, 2014|language=Japanese}} The limited edition came bundled with the [[remix album]] ''[[Air soundtracks#Ornithopter|Ornithopter]]'' remixing background music tracks featured in the visual novel. The regular edition was released on July 27, 2001.{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/product/air/|title=''Air'' visual novel official website|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|accessdate=November 30, 2007|language=Japanese}} Key released on all ages version on July 27, 2001 for Windows. An updated adult version called the ''Air Standard Edition'' was released on April 8, 2005 with added support for [[Windows 2000]]/[[Windows XP|XP]] as a [[DVD-ROM]].{{cite web|url=http://www.product.co.jp/products/item/157/|title=Air Standard Edition|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|accessdate=December 19, 2014|language=Japanese}} An updated all ages version of ''Air'' compatible for [[Windows Vista]] PCs was released by Key on July 31, 2009 in a box set containing five other Key visual novels called Key 10th Memorial Box.{{cite web|url= http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/10thfes/memorialbox.htm|title=Key 10th Memorial Box official website|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|accessdate=April 6, 2009|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090403015835/http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/10thfes/memorialbox.htm| archivedate= 3 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} Another updated all ages version compatible for [[Windows 7]] PCs called ''Air Memorial Edition'' was released on May 28, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/info/2010/04/post_73.html |title=Keyの過去五作品がメモリアルエディションで発売です! |trans-title=Key's Previous Five Titles Get Memorial Editions! |publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]] |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=April 8, 2010 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410213035/http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/info/2010/04/post_73.html |archivedate=10 April 2010 |deadurl=yes }} The first consumer console [[Porting|port]] of the game was released for the [[Dreamcast]] (DC) on September 20, 2001 by [[Interchannel|NEC Interchannel]].{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B00006LJG4/|title=Air|publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.jp]]|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://sega.jp/dc/010804/home.shtml |title=Air |publisher=[[Sega]] |accessdate=May 31, 2013 |language=Japanese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150724122321/http://sega.jp/dc/010804/home.shtml |archivedate=July 24, 2015 }} A [[PlayStation 2]] (PS2) version was released on August 8, 2002 also by NEC Interchannel.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B000069E08/|title=Air|publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.jp]]|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language=Japanese}} The PS2 version was re-released as a "[[The Best (PlayStation range)|Best]]" version on September 1, 2005.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125010459/http://www.interchannel.co.jp/gamesoft/g99905083063.html|url=http://www.interchannel.co.jp/gamesoft/g99905083063.html|title=Air ベスト版|trans-title=Air Best edition|publisher=[[Interchannel]]|archivedate=January 25, 2007|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language=Japanese}} The PS2 version was bundled in a "Key 3-Part Work Premium Box" package together with the PS2 versions of ''Kanon'' and ''[[Clannad (visual novel)|Clannad]]'' released on July 30, 2009.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716022102/http://www.gunghoworks.jp/game/3title/index.html|url=http://www.gunghoworks.jp/game/3title/index.html|title=key3部作プレミアムBOX|trans-title=Key 3-part Work Premium BOX|publisher=GungHo Works|archivedate=July 16, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language=Japanese}} To compensate for the lack of erotic content in the consumer ports, extra scenes were added. A version playable on [[SoftBank Mobile|SoftBank 3G]] [[mobile phone]]s was released by [[Prototype (company)|Prototype]] through [[VisualArt's|VisualArt's Motto]]{{cite web|url=http://www.prot.co.jp/voda/air/index.html|title=Air|publisher=[[Prototype (company)|Prototype]]|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language=Japanese}} on May 1, 2007. Prototype later released a [[Video Graphics Array|VGA]] edition produced by [[NTT DoCoMo]] playable on [[Freedom of Mobile Multimedia Access|FOMA]] phones in February 2008.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206213442/http://motto.product.co.jp/|url=http://motto.product.co.jp/index.php?mode=res_view&no=217|title=Official VisualArt's Motto blog entry for the Air VGA mobile phone release|publisher=[[VisualArt's]]|archivedate=February 6, 2008|date=February 5, 2008|accessdate=September 6, 2008|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/info/2008/02/fomavgaair.html|title=Official Key blog entry for the VGA ''Air'' mobile phone release|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|date=February 5, 2008|accessdate=February 6, 2008|language= Japanese}} The version for the FOMA phones was split into two separate files: the Dream story arc comprised the first file, and the remaining Summer and Air arcs comprised the second file.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005051120/http://motto.product.co.jp/appli.html|url=http://motto.product.co.jp/appli.html|title=List of cell phone games playable through VisualArt's Motto|publisher=[[VisualArt's|VisualArt's Motto]]|archivedate=October 5, 2008|accessdate=February 10, 2012|language= Japanese}} A version of the Dream arc playable on [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices was released on July 27, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/513/513261/|title=名作『AIR』DREAM編が完全フルボイスでAndroidアプリとして配信|trans-title=The Dream Arc from the Masterpiece Air is Distributed as an Android App with Completely Full Voice|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=July 27, 2012|accessdate=July 28, 2012|language=Japanese}} A version containing the Summer and Air arcs for Android devices was released on August 15, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/522/522605/|title=『AIR』の『SUMMER・AIR編』と『メイデンハロー』が本日からGooglePlayで配信開始|trans-title=Air's Summer and Air Chapters and Maiden Halo are Being Distributed on GooglePlay Starting Today|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=August 15, 2012|accessdate=September 13, 2012|language=Japanese}} A full version ''Air'' on Android devices was released on October 24, 2012 in two editions: one without voice acting, and one with voice acting, including Yukito.{{cite web|url=http://news.mynavi.jp/news/2012/10/25/093/|title=ビジュアルアーツ、Android版『AIR』の一括ダウンロード版を配信開始|trans-title=An All Together Download Edition of Air on Android Starts Distribution from VisualArt's|publisher=Mynavi|date=October 25, 2012|accessdate=October 25, 2012|language=Japanese}} Two versions were released on May 2, 2013: an adult version for Android devices and an all ages version playable on [[iOS]] devices.{{cite web|url=http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/info/2013/05/air_iosair_18android.html|title=『AIR 全年齢版』がiOSで『AIR 18禁版』がAndroidで登場!|trans-title=Air All Ages Edition is on iOS and Air 18+ Edition is on Android!|publisher=[[Key (company)|Key]]|date=May 2, 2013|accessdate=May 3, 2013|language=Japanese}} A [[PlayStation Portable]] (PSP) version of the game was released in Japan on November 22, 2007 by Prototype.{{cite web|url=http://www.prot.co.jp/psp/air/index.html|title=Air|publisher=[[Prototype (company)|Prototype]]|accessdate=August 30, 2007|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070825162200/http://www.prot.co.jp/psp/air/index.html| archivedate= August 25, 2007 | deadurl= no}} A downloadable version of the PSP release via the [[PlayStation Store]] was released by Prototype on September 2, 2010. A [[PlayStation Vita]] (PSV) version was released by Prototype on September 8, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.prot.co.jp/psv/air/index.html|title=Air|publisher=[[Prototype (company)|Prototype]]|accessdate=May 3, 2016|language=Japanese}} In the original release, there was no voice acting for the characters, though this was later changed for the DC version, which except for Yukito included full voice acting, and the PS2, PSP and PSV versions, which had full voice acting. ==Adaptations== ===Manga=== An ''Air'' [[manga]] was serialized in the Japanese [[computer game]] magazine ''[[Comptiq]]'' between August 10, 2004 and February 10, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.comptiq.com/release/comptiq/2004_09.html |title=''Comptiq'' September 2004 issue |publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]] |accessdate=June 25, 2006 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630101532/http://www.comptiq.com/release/comptiq/2004_09.html |archivedate=June 30, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The individual chapters were later collected into two separate [[Tankōbon|volumes]] published by [[Kadokawa Shoten]]. The story was adapted from the visual novel version that preceded it, and was illustrated by [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[Mangaka|artist]] [[Yukimaru Katsura]]. Between the two volumes, there are 15 main chapters (nine in volume one and six in volume two), and two [[Omake|bonus]] chapters included at the end of each volume.{{cite book|last=Katsura|first=Yukimaru|title=Air manga volume 1|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|language=Japanese}}{{cite book|last=Katsura|first=Yukimaru|title=Air manga volume 2|publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]|language=Japanese}} The manga version goes through the Dream and Air arcs in detail while the Summer arc is only touched upon briefly throughout the manga. The main focus is on Misuzu's story with Kano and Minagi serving as minor characters in comparison. However, Minagi's story is explained in the bonus installment at the end of volume two. There are also five sets of manga [[anthology|anthologies]] produced by different companies and drawn by a multitude of different artists. The first volume of the earliest anthology series, released by [[Ichijinsha]] under the title ''Air Comic Anthology'', was released on January 25, 2001 under their ''DNA Media Comics'' label. Volumes for this series continued to be released until December 25, 2001 with the seventh volume. The second anthology, ''Air Anthology Comic'', was released in a single volume by Softgarage on December 20, 2002. On April 17, 2004, Ohzora released an anthology composed of works based on both ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'' and ''Air'' titled ''Haru Urara: Kanon & Air''. Ohzora also released three other anthologies under the title ''Air'', the last of which came out on March 24, 2005. The last manga anthology was released as a single volume on April 2, 2005 by [[Jive (publisher)|Jive]] titled ''Comic Anthology Air: Kimi no Iru Basho''. Each of the anthology series are written and drawn by an average of 20 people per volume.{{cite web|url= http://www.ohzora.co.jp/release/detail/?format=comics&isbn=4-7767-1580-5|title=Official listing for the third volume of the manga anthology ''Air''|publisher=Ohzora|accessdate=February 26, 2008|language=Japanese}} ===Drama CDs=== There were nine [[Radio drama in Japan|drama CDs]] released based on ''Air'' released by [[Lantis (company)|Lantis]].{{cite web|url= http://lantis.jp/release/data.php?id=227|title=Official listing for the nine ''Air'' drama CDs|publisher=[[Lantis (company)|Lantis]]|accessdate=February 18, 2008|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080325145709/http://lantis.jp/release/data.php?id=227| archivedate= 25 March 2008 | deadurl= no}} The first three focused solely on each of the main heroines separately per CD where the cover of the album would depict which of the girls to be presented. These three albums were released on August 24, 2005. The next set of three was done the same way and released on October 21, 2005. The last three were released in one month increments after the second batch of three drama CDs went on sale. The seventh CD focused on the events of the Summer arc in the story while the last two were based on the Air arc. At least the last CD released on January 25, 2006 contained original stories in addition to the story from the visual novel.{{cite web|url= http://www.cdjapan.co.jp/detailview.html?KEY=FCCP-17|title=The ninth ''Air'' drama CD|publisher=CD Japan|accessdate=January 11, 2007|language=Japanese}} ===Anime series=== [[File:Air TV DVD Vol 01.png|right|thumb|175px|The cover of the first DVD compilation volume for the ''Air'' anime series.]] {{see also|List of Air episodes}} On November 17, 2004, a teaser [[DVD]] named "Air prelude" was produced containing interviews with the anime's cast, clean opening and ending theme video sequences, and promotional footage of the anime itself; it was a limited edition DVD, with only 20,000 copies produced. The [[anime]] television series is produced by [[Kyoto Animation]], directed by [[Tatsuya Ishihara]], written by [[Fumihiko Shimo]], and features character design by Tomoe Aratani who based the designs on [[Itaru Hinoue]]'s original concept. Thirteen episodes were produced by Kyoto Animation: 12 regular episodes, and a final [[Abridgement|recap]] episode which summarizes Misuzu's [[story arc]]. The anime also follows the game by splitting the series into three parts; Dream (episodes one through seven), Summer (episodes eight and nine), and Air (episodes 10 through 12), with the recap episode (episode 13) following. The episodes aired between January 6 and March 31, 2005 on the [[BS-i]] Japanese [[television network]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/story/story.html|title=Official website listing of all TV episodes|publisher=[[BS-i]]| accessdate=April 27, 2007|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070414154129/http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/story/story.html| archivedate= 14 April 2007 | deadurl= no}} The theme songs from the ''Air'' visual novel are used for the anime's opening theme, ending theme and soundtrack. After the conclusion of the anime series, a mini-series which added to the Summer arc of the story called ''Air in Summer'' aired on August 28 and September 4, 2005 a week later on BS-i. ''Air in Summer'' consisted of two episodes and was produced by the same staff as the anime series. A DVD released on March 31, 2005 called "Air Memories" contained promotional commercials for the series, staff commentaries, and clean ending sequences from the 12th and 13th episodes, lasting 92 minutes.{{cite web |url=http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/info/dvd.html|title=DVD section at the anime's official website|publisher=[[Tokyo Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=March 26, 2008|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080401134821/http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/info/dvd.html| archivedate= 1 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} The episodes were released to [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] DVD between April 6 and September 7, 2005 by [[Pony Canyon]] in limited and regular editions containing two episodes per volume. The DVD for ''Air in Summer'' was later released on October 5, 2005 in Japan. Additionally, ''Air'' became one of the first anime series to be released in [[Blu-ray Disc]] format on December 22, 2006.{{cite web|url= http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/info/blue.html|title=Blue-ray box set release information at the anime's official website|publisher=[[Tokyo Broadcasting System]]|accessdate=March 26, 2008|language=Japanese| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080401134819/http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/info/blue.html| archivedate= 1 April 2008 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://av.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20060720/pony.htm|title=''Air'' sells on Blu-Ray format|publisher=Watch Impress|language=Japanese|accessdate=March 26, 2007}} A new version of the Blu-ray Disc box set was released on November 28, 2008 in Japan. On April 27, 2007, [[ADV Films]] co-founder and executive [[Matt Greenfield]] announced the acquisition of both the anime series and the film during a panel at the [[anime convention]] [[Anime Matsuri]];{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-04-27/adv-announces-acquistion-of-air-tv-series-air-movie|title=ADV Announces Acquisition of ''Air'' TV Series, ''Air'' Movie|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=April 27, 2007|accessdate=April 27, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070430013136/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2007-04-27/adv-announces-acquistion-of-air-tv-series-air-movie| archivedate= 30 April 2007 | deadurl= no}} it paid $145,000 for the TV series.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-01-30/adv-court-documents-reveal-amounts-paid-for-29-anime-titles|title=ADV Court Documents Reveal Amounts Paid for 29 Anime Titles|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=January 30, 2012|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} The 12 main episodes and two ''Air in Summer'' episodes were licensed for North American distribution by ADV Films.{{cite web|url= http://www.advfilms.com/titles/airtv/index.html|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070614013120/http://www.advfilms.com/titles/airtv/index.html|archivedate=June 14, 2007|title=ADV Films' official ''Air'' anime website|publisher=[[ADV Films]]|accessdate=March 26, 2008}} The episodes were released on four DVD compilations between August 14 and November 27, 2007. The second DVD volume was sold in two editions, with the difference between the two being a series box all four DVDs could fit inside. In July 2008, the license for the anime series and film was transferred to [[Funimation]], which continued to produce them in North America in English.{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-07-04/funimation-picks-up-over-30-former-ad-vision-titles|title=Funimation Picks Up Over 30 Former AD Vision Titles|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=July 4, 2008|accessdate=July 7, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080707034228/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2008-07-04/funimation-picks-up-over-30-former-ad-vision-titles| archivedate= 7 July 2008 | deadurl= no}} Funimation released a three-disc series box set of the ''Air'' anime on April 21, 2009,{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B001R10BB4/ |title=''Air'': The Complete Series|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=June 7, 2009}} which did not include the recap episode. ===Film=== {{main|Air (2005 film)}} An ''Air'' [[anime|animated film]] directed by [[Osamu Dezaki]] premiered in Japanese theaters on February 5, 2005.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027092320/http://www.air2004.com/news.htm|url=http://www.air2004.com/news.htm|title=''Air'' film official website news section|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|date=February 5, 2005|archivedate=October 27, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012|language=Japanese}} The film, animated by [[Toei Animation]],{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028133813/http://www.air2004.com/|url=http://www.air2004.com/|title=''Air'' film official website|publisher=[[Toei Animation]]|archivedate=October 28, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012|language=Japanese}} is a reinterpretation of the original ''Air'' storyline which centers on the [[story arc]] of the female lead Misuzu Kamio. Yukito Kunisaki arrives in the town of Kami for a chance to earn money at the summer festival and meets Misuzu on his first day in town. They soon become friends and a story one thousand years old begins to unfold. The film was later sold on [[DVD]] and released in three editions: the Collector's Edition, the Special Edition, and the Regular Edition on August 5, 2005.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027092320/http://www.air2004.com/news.htm#DVD|url=http://www.air2004.com/news.htm#DVD|title=''Air'' film official website on the DVD features|publisher=[[Frontier Works]]|archivedate=October 27, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012|language=Japanese}} The ''Air'' film was originally released on DVD by [[ADV Films]] in North America on December 11, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-09-24/adv-bandai-visual-set-release-dates|title=ADV, Bandai Visual Set Release Dates|date=September 24, 2007|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=March 21, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090213185305/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-09-24/adv-bandai-visual-set-release-dates| archivedate= 13 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[Funimation]] continued the release of the film as of July 2008 when the license was transferred from ADV to Funimation; Funimation re-released the film on April 21, 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B001R10BAU/ |title=''Air: The Motion Picture''|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=March 21, 2009}} ==Music== {{main|Music of Air}} The visual novel has three main theme songs: the opening theme {{Nihongo|"[[Tori no Uta]]"|鳥の詩|Bird's Poem}}, the ending theme "Farewell song", and {{Nihongo|"Aozora"|青空|Blue Skies}} as an insert song. Each song is sung by [[Lia (singer)|Lia]] of [[I've Sound]] and the lyrics were written by [[Jun Maeda]].{{cite web|url=http://respect-maeda.com/sounds.html|title= Key Sounds Label albums with contributions by Jun Maeda|publisher=Respect Maeda|accessdate=April 25, 2008|language=Japanese| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080216012404/http://respect-maeda.com/sounds.html| archivedate = February 16, 2008}} Five of the characters have [[leitmotif]]s, or [[background music]] theme songs—the three heroines, Kanna, and Michiru.{{cite web|url=http://www15.plala.or.jp/scp/key/air_soundtrack.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604005236/http://www15.plala.or.jp/scp/key/air_soundtrack.html|archivedate=June 4, 2008|title=''Air Original Soundtrack'' booklet transcribed online|accessdate=May 29, 2008|language=Japanese}} Misuzu's theme is {{Nihongo|"Natsukage"|夏影|Summer Lights}}; Kano's theme is {{Nihongo|"Mizutamari"|水たまり|Puddle}}; Minagi's theme is {{Nihongo|"Niji"|虹|Rainbows}}; Kanna's theme is {{Nihongo|"Tsukiwarawa"|月童|Moon Child}}; lastly, Michiru's theme is {{Nihongo|"Tentōmushi"|てんとう虫|Ladybug}}. Of the six music tracks not used in the visual novel, but of which were included on the game's original soundtrack, the first two were failed attempts at creating a theme for Minagi. The first album, ''[[Music of Air#Ornithopter|Ornithopter]]'', came bundled with the original release of ''Air'' in September 2000. The next album was released in August 2001 as a [[maxi single]] titled "[[Music of Air#Natsukage / Nostalgia|Natsukage / Nostalgia]]" containing a vocal version of "Natsukage", and a [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] track; both songs were sung by Lia and the rest of the single was produced by Jun Maeda. The [[Music of Air#Air Original Soundtrack|game's original soundtrack]] was released in September 2002 containing two discs with 31 different tracks along with remix and instrumental versions of the opening and ending themes.{{cite web|url=http://key.soundslabel.com/discography.htm |title=Key Sounds Label's discography |publisher=[[Key Sounds Label]] |accessdate=April 25, 2008 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418030319/http://key.soundslabel.com/discography.htm |archivedate=April 18, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} A piano [[Arrangement|arrange]] album was released in December 2003 called ''[[Music of Air#Re-feel|Re-feel]]'' which contained five tracks from ''Air'' and five from ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]''. An [[Extended play|EP]] containing original versions of the three theme songs and remixed versions of the opening and ending themes was released in May 2006 called ''[[Music of Air#Air Analog Collector's Edition|Air Analog Collector's Edition: Tori no Uta / Farewell song]]''. Each of the albums released for the visual novel version were released on Key's [[record label]] [[Key Sounds Label]]. The [[Music of Air#Air Film Soundtrack|film's original soundtrack]] was released in March 2005 by [[Frontier Works]].{{cite web|url= https://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0007N378C/ |title=''Air Film Soundtrack''|publisher=[[Amazon.com|Amazon.co.jp]]|accessdate=April 25, 2008|language=Japanese}} A bonus [[symphony]] CD titled ''[[Music of Air#Shinwa e no Izanai|Shinwa e no Izanai]]'' was released with the special edition ''Air'' film DVD on August 5, 2005.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027092320/http://www.air2004.com/news.htm#sp|url=http://www.air2004.com/news.htm#sp|title=''Air'' film special edition DVD listing at the film's official website| publisher=[[Frontier Works]]|archivedate=October 27, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012|language=Japanese}} Overall, ''Air''{{'s}} music has been well received, and the original soundtrack for the visual novel has met with high sales.{{cite web|url= http://www.hentai.co.uk/articles/air_information_and_synopsis.html|title=Air information and synopsis|publisher=Hentai.co.uk| accessdate=January 12, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070107005742/http://www.hentai.co.uk/articles/air_information_and_synopsis.html| archivedate= 7 January 2007 | deadurl= no}} The opening theme was involved in [[copyright]] infringement in 2005.{{cite web|url= http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-09-21/air-plagiarisation-follow-up| title=Air Plagiarisation Follow-Up|date=September 21, 2005|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=May 5, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080607115027/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-09-21/air-plagiarisation-follow-up| archivedate= 7 June 2008 | deadurl= no}} ==Reception and sales== According to a national ranking of how well [[bishōjo game]]s sold nationally in Japan, the original ''Air'' PC release premiered at number one in the rankings.{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051227185754/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank66.html|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank66.html |title=PC News national ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 1, 42, and 42|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The game ranked twice at 42 in November and December 2000, at 20 in January 2001, and twice more at 42 through February 2001.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227171208/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank67.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank67.html|title=PC News national ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 20|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227174428/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank69.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank69.html|title=PC News national ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 42 and 42|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The original release appeared on the charts twice more: the first in late September to early October 2001 at 26,{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227182829/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank85.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank85.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 26|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} and again in the last two weeks of May 2002, ranking in at 43.{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051227185607/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank100.html|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank100.html |title=PC News nation ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 43|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=June 14, 2007|language=Japanese}} The regular edition of the ''Air'' PC release premiered at number 13, ranked in at number 41 in the following ranking, and 42 in the ranking after that.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227180156/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank84.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank84.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 42|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The PC all ages version premiered at number seven in the rankings and had a final ranking at 30 in the next ranking.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227185930/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank82.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank82.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 7 and 30|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The ''Air Standard Edition'' premiered at number one in the rankings.{{cite web|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20051227181858/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank169.html|url=http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank169.html |title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 1|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 27, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} The ''Air Standard Edition'' ranked in twice more, at 34 and at 28 in the next two rankings.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051218034042/http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank171.html|url= http://www.peakspub.co.jp/ranking/rank171.html|title=PC News ranking for bishōjo games; Air ranks 34 and 28|publisher=Peakspub|archivedate=December 18, 2005 |accessdate=March 13, 2007|language=Japanese}} ''Air'' was the highest selling game of 2000 selling 102,080 units, which was about 25,000 more units than the second highest game, ''Inagawa de Ikō!''.{{cite web|url=http://astore.amazon.co.jp/wikimania-22/listmania/R2KDYRRCZNA20X/249-7991717-8843508|title=Amazon store with ranking list for highest selling bishōjo games of 2000|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=May 17, 2008|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001144904/http://astore.amazon.co.jp/wikimania-22/listmania/R2KDYRRCZNA20X/249-7991717-8843508|archivedate=October 1, 2011|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} The Dreamcast version sold 42,445 units in its first week, and was the fourth highest selling console game in Japan that week.{{cite web|url= http://www.xmission.com/pub/lists/ngamers/archive/ngamers.200110|title=''Air'' DC game first week sales|publisher=Xmission| date=September 28, 2001|accessdate=May 16, 2008| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080603031346/http://www.xmission.com/pub/lists/ngamers/archive/ngamers.200110| archivedate= 3 June 2008 | deadurl= no}} The video game magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'' scored this version a 30 out of 40,{{cite journal|title=Dreamcast: Air|journal=[[Weekly Famitsu]]|issue=915, pt. 2|page=54|date=June 30, 2006|language=Japanese}} and it ultimately sold 50,406 units to rank as the 53rd highest selling Japanese Dreamcast game ever, as of 2007.{{cite web|url=http://moorangol.altervista.org/others/dreamcast.html |title=Ranking of highest selling Japanese Dreamcast games |publisher=Altervista |accessdate=January 11, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061211200339/http://moorangol.altervista.org/others/dreamcast.html |archivedate=11 December 2006 |deadurl=yes }} NTT Publishing reported that over 300,000 units of ''Air'' have been sold.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070821161159/http://eg.nttpub.co.jp/pickup/20060221spe01_01.html|url=http://eg.nttpub.co.jp/pickup/20060221spe01_01.html|title=Clannad|publisher=NTT Publishing|archivedate=August 21, 2007|accessdate=February 16, 2012|language=Japanese}} "''Air'' took the bishōjo gaming world by storm," as states a review of the Dreamcast game by [[MobyGames]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/dreamcast/air-/reviews/reviewerId,42377/ |title=Dreamcast review |publisher=[[MobyGames]] |date=April 6, 2005 |accessdate=January 17, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110182517/http://www.mobygames.com/game/dreamcast/air-/reviews/reviewerId%2C42377/ |archivedate=November 10, 2012 }} ''Air'' was described as a game that stands out, much like Key's first title ''[[Kanon (visual novel)|Kanon]]'', due to an intricate plot that keeps the player interested, and has a good replay value as well. In an interview of [[Jun Maeda]] and [[Yūichi Suzumoto]], they were both surprised to find out that the Japanese public (in March 2001) felt ''Air'' to be a soothing game, but Maeda and Suzumoto made it clear that this impression is completely at odds with their impression of the game, and they remark that there was not one person who worked on ''Air'' who thought that. Characters from ''Air'' have appeared in [[dōjin]] works not directly based on the ''Air'' series. Games such as ''[[Eternal Fighter Zero|Eternal Fighter Zero -Blue Sky Edition-]]'' by [[Twilight Frontier]] where most of the playable characters either came from ''Air'' or from the earlier [[Key (company)|Key]] games ''Kanon'' or ''[[One: Kagayaku Kisetsu e|One]]''.{{cite web|url=http://pirikara.net/games/show/efzbse|title=''Eternal Fighter Zero -Blue Sky Edition-''|publisher=Pirikara|accessdate=January 12, 2006|language=Japanese}} In the October 2007 issue of ''[[Dengeki G's Magazine]]'', poll results for the 50 best bishōjo games were released. Out of 249 titles, ''Air'' ranked eighth with 43 votes.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011213916/http://gs.dengekinet.com/ranking/index.html|url=http://gs.dengeki.com/ranking/index.html|title=Dengeki G's Magazine top 50 bishōjo games|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|archivedate=October 11, 2007|accessdate=January 3, 2011|language= Japanese}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=n|30em}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|Air (visual novel)}} *[http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/product/air/ Key's official ''Air'' website] {{ja icon}} *[http://www.tbs.co.jp/anime/air/ ''Air'' anime official website] {{ja icon}} *{{Vndb|36||Air}} *{{IMDb title|0940874}} *{{ann|anime|2480|Air}} {{Key (company)|state=expanded}} {{Kyoto Animation}} {{good article}} [[Category:2000 video games]] [[Category:2004 manga]] [[Category:2005 anime television series]] [[Category:Air (series)| ]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Bishōjo games]] [[Category:Dreamcast games]] [[Category:Eroge]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Funimation]] [[Category:Ichijinsha manga]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Japan-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Kadokawa Shoten manga]] [[Category:Key (company) games]] [[Category:Kyoto Animation]] [[Category:Lantis (company)]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:Romance video games]] [[Category:School life in anime and manga]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Tragedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Visual novels]] [[Category:Windows games]]

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=May 2012}} {{primary sources|date=May 2010}} }}
{{Infobox video game |title = Armored Core 2: Another Age |image = Armored Core 2 - Another Age.jpg |caption = North American PlayStation 2 cover art |developer = [[FromSoftware]] |publisher = {{Vgrelease|NA|[[Agetec]]|EU|[[Metro 3D]]|JP|[[FromSoftware]]}} |designer = |engine = |series = ''[[Armored Core]]'' |platforms = [[PlayStation 2]] |released = {{Vgrelease|JP|April 12, 2001|NA|August 20, 2001|EU|September 27, 2002}} |genre = [[Action game|Action]], [[third-person shooter]] |modes = [[Single player video game|Single player]], [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Armored Core 2: Another Age''''' is a [[mecha]] [[third-person shooter]] video game in the ''[[Armored Core]]'' series, developed by [[FromSoftware]], which also published it in Japan, for the [[PlayStation 2]] in 2001. [[Agetec]] and [[Metro 3D]] released the game in North America and Europe respectively.
==Storyline== Five years after [[Armored Core 2|the coup attempt led by Leos Klein]] the Earth government struggles to realize one of its original objectives, relocating people from the underground cities to the Earth's surface. These plans are hopelessly delayed because the government has had to shift its focus from resettlement to military buildup. A necessary move in the government's eyes, needed to keep both the corporations and the situation on Mars in check. After facing various setbacks, the corporations that once held sway on Mars are in positions of diminished influence. This does not sit well with them and each is secretly rebuilding their personal armies in order to contend with the government's growing might. Tensions between the corporations and government are at a breaking point. With all of the government's efforts currently focused elsewhere, resentment toward the institution from the general populace is at an all-time high. Tired of being neglected, people living in the underground cities have taken matters into their own hands and incidents of armed revolt are a daily occurrence.
==Background==
===Corporations=== *'''Zio Matrix''' - Following a failed coup attempt (through which Zio hoped to strengthen its power base by exploiting Disorder technology), the parent company sidestepped most repercussions by discreetly transferring blame to its Mars division, claiming it acted alone. Even so, Zio Matrix now toes a fine line with the government and is more circumspect in its dealings. *'''Emeraude''' - After an all-out clash with the LCC on Mars, Emeraude's position has been significantly weakened. In a bid to combat the government's increasing influence and regain lost ground, Emeraude actively pursues confrontation and is the most volatile corporate element. *'''Balena''' - Due to the Frighteners overstepping their authority, Balena and the LCC's efforts to reshuffle the power structure on Mars failed. Balena's ties with both Zio and Emeraude are all but severed, now that the company's involvement with the government is public knowledge. Balena continues to provide assistance to the government, but it is also secretly backing the Indies rebel group.
===Government=== *'''The Earth Government''' - Under the [[tagline]] "The Central Union of [[Earth]]", the Earth government is exactly what its name suggests it is; a singular governmental body serving the entire planet. After [[Armored Core: Master of Arena|the end of the subterranean era]] and the downfall of the [[Armored Core (video game)#Corporations|Earth-based corporations]] the government rebuilt itself into the ruling body it was prior to the "Great Destruction". The government relies primarily on proxies like the Bureaus of Control and the LCC to govern locally while it focuses on the environmental reclamation and the repopulation of Earth's surface. After being [[Armored Core 2|betrayed by the Frighteners]], the government has become reluctant to employ Ravens unless circumstances are dire and Ravens are not allowed to enter Earth Central, the capital city of Earth. **'''Bureaus of Control (BOC)''' - Administrative bodies set in place by the government. BOC's exist in all major Earth cities and are tasked with supervising development, regulating corporate activity, and maintaining order in their respective cities and the surrounding areas. Bureau names indicate their area of jurisdiction, for example, Neo Isaac Bureau of Control.
===Independent Groups=== *'''Indies''' - A large, well-financed rebel group that plots against both the government and corporations in a bid to overthrow them and establish a new governing body. Its ranks consist mainly of the poor and disenfranchised, but a number of Ravens have taken up the cause as well. *'''Nerves Concord''' - The Nerves Concord continues its role as both Arena operator and impartial middleman between the corporations and Ravens. Though siding with no one, the Nerves Concord's function perpetuates corporate rivalries.
==Gameplay== The expansion to ''[[Armored Core 2]]'' runs on the same game engine as its predecessor but features a number of changes in the way the game is played. There is no trial mission in Another Age that kicks the game off, the player is simply thrown into the world with their AC and their first job offer right there waiting for them. The Arena, which played a significant role in ''Armored Core 2'' has been removed completely, along with the "Arena Report" in your save data, but a fair number of the game's missions involve one-on-one combat with other Ravens in a set-up not unlike ''Armored Core 2'''s Arena. Another Age has sparse expressed plot, it is more a portrait of the life of a mercenary, always bouncing about from place to place and not getting tied down to any one particular cause. Occasionally recurring elements pop up from time to time as the game progresses, but there is no defined storyline to the game. While there is virtually no storyline there are 100 separate missions that make up the mass of the game, the largest ''Armored Core'' title to date, and each mission plays out in a specific area of the world map screen that would reappear in following AC titles down the road. Another Age is also noted for its cameo appearances. Past enemies from previous ''Armored Core'' games Stinger and Nineball appear as bosses in several special missions that are unlocked once you clear all 100 of the game's missions.
Also of note is that for the first time in the Armored Core series, analog controls are supported. While Armored Core 2 did use the analog stick buttons (L3 and R3) on the [[DualShock 2]], player control was still based on the D-pad and whatever other buttons were mapped to view/motion control. However, this is limited to using the left analog stick for forward/backward movement and turning similarly to the D-pad. [[Armored Core: Nexus]] would become the first game to fully utilize dual-stick controls for both movement and aiming, offering it as the default scheme.
==Reception== On release, ''[[Famitsu]]'' magazine scored the game a 35 out of 40.<ref>''プレイステーション2 - ARMORED CORE 2 ANOTHER AGE''. Weekly Famitsu. No.915 Pt.2. Pg.61. 30 June 2006.</ref>

{{MI| {{third-party|date=May 2018}} {{Underlinked|date=June 2016}} }} The '''Association of Performing Arts Professionals''' (previously the Association of Performing Arts Presenters, also known as '''APAP'''), based in [[Washington, D.C.]],<ref name=about>[http://www.apap365.org/About/Pages/default.aspx "About" page], apap365.org, official site of APAP. Accessed online 2013-01-14.</ref> is the [[United States]] national service, advocacy and membership organization for the [[performing arts]] presenting sector and the convener of APAP|NYC, the world’s leading gathering of performing arts professionals, every January in [[New York City]].
Founded in 1957, APAP is a [[501(c)(3) organization]] governed by a volunteer board of directors and led by President and CEO Mario Garcia Durham.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apap365.org/ABOUT/staff/Pages/MarioGarciaDurham.aspx|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==History==
APAP's story begins in the 1950s when college and university concert managers directed their interests toward the educational role of the arts and the unique issues related to professional performing arts on campus. Fan Taylor, presenter at the [[Wisconsin Union Theater]], became the founder of APAP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apap365.org/ABOUT/WhoWeAre/Pages/fan-taylor.aspx|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> [[The University of Wisconsin]] in Madison initially housed the staff. During the 1960s and 1970s, the presenting field and membership expanded to a variety of organizations, prompting the association to change its name to the Association of College, University and Community Arts Administrators (ACUCAA) in 1973. By the mid-1980s, colleges and universities no longer dominated the membership, and the association’s spectrum expanded. The organization’s name was changed to the Association of Performing Arts Presenters in 1988. Fan Taylor led the organization for 24 years. Bill Dawson succeeded Taylor in 1971 and served until 1986, when Susie Farr became the third executive director until her departure in 1999. During her tenure the national office relocated to [[Washington,_D.C.|Washington, D.C.]] Sandra Gibson served as president and CEO from 2000 until 2011. In October 2011, the board of directors appointed Mario Garcia Durham as president and CEO, the fifth leader of APAP.<ref>{{cite web|title=APAP's History|url=http://www.apap365.org/ABOUT/WhoWeAre/Pages/history.aspx|website=apap365.org}}</ref>
==Membership== Membership in the association was 29 in 1957; by 1966 it had increased to 275. Today APAP has 1,600 organizational and individual members and serves more than 5,000 performing arts professionals every year. Today, the association represents the nonprofit and for-profit sectors of the presenting and touring industry of the performing arts in the U.S. and internationally, with member organizations from all 50 U.S. states and at least 50 countries.<ref name=about /> Members include large performing arts centers in major cities, outdoor festivals, rural community-focused organizations, academic institutions, individual artists, and artist managers and booking agents, and representing disciplines including various forms of dance, music, theater, puppetry, circus, magic, attractions and performance art.
==Programs==
Through professional development programs and resources, APAP helps artists, agents, managers, presenters and producers to gain the knowledge, skills and strategies they need to make the arts a vibrant, valuable and sustainable part of everyday life. APAP enriches communities by supporting this work through grants, resources and advocacy aimed at making the arts accessible for all. APAP programs focus on broadening the impact of the performing arts to all audiences and to all citizens. As a founding member of the Performing Arts Alliance, APAP advocates for national policies that support, strengthen and improve the performing arts industry.
=== APAP|NYC ===
The association holds an annual members-only conference in New York City every January called APAP|NYC. The 2017 event—the 60th anniversary of the conference—featured more than 1,000 artist showcase performances, and more than 3,680 arts professionals from 50 states and 36 countries attended. An extensive array of performing arts events and festivals take place each January in [[New York City]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.apap365.org/Conference|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> January 12–16, will greet more than 3,600 presenters, artists, managers, agents and emerging arts leaders for five days of professional development, business deals and exciting performances.
=== Professional development ===
Through professional development programs and resources, APAP helps artists, agents, managers, presenters and producers to gain the knowledge, skills and strategies they need to make the arts a vibrant, valuable and sustainable part of everyday life. APAP provides year-round resources for Professional Development and Networking including access to the Membership Database, joining Fellowship programs, and monthly webinars.
Every January in [[New York City]], APAP hosts [apapnyc.org], the world's leading gathering of performing arts professionals. A core component of this five-day-long event is professional development, with more than 80 sessions, including artist pitch sessions, pre-conference seminars, individual consultations, and plenary events with featured guest speakers.
=== Leadership programs ===
Emerging Leadership Institute (2002–present): Annual two-day intensive seminar for cohort of 20-30 emerging leaders at APAP|NYC.
Leadership Fellows Program (2015–present): Leadership Fellows Program (LFP) is a 20-month-long program for mid-career professionals.
Leadership Development Institute (2009-2013): Two cohorts of 10-15 mid-career professionals research "Mission/Vision" and "Connecting to Your Community" and produced the online interactive toolkit.
Monthly Webinar Series (2012–present): APAP hosts a monthly professional development webinar series designed specifically for arts professionals and free for all APAP members. These online seminars present discussions led by arts industry experts, innovators and creative leaders.
Young Performers Career Advancement (1996–Present): Taking place at APAP|NYC, the Young Performers Career Advancement Program (YPCA) is a series of intensive seminars designed to support classical musicians in the formative stages of their careers by offering opportunities to meet and work with established presenters, managers, agents and artists.
=== Grant Programs ===
''APAP offers several grant programs exclusively for APAP members to provide financial support that recognizes outstanding and innovative practice.''
Building Bridges (2013–Present): Building Bridges is a program that supports campus based presenters interested in building interdisciplinary cross campus and community collaborations that expand knowledge and understanding of Muslim societies.
Cultural Exchange Fund (2008–Present): The Cultural Exchange Fund is a travel subsidy program to assist U.S. based presenting professionals and artists in building partnerships and collaborations with international colleagues and to experience the work of artists from around the world in its cultural context.
==Notes== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
In [[mathematical logic]], '''projective determinacy''' is the special case of the [[axiom of determinacy]] applying only to [[projective set]]s.
The '''axiom of projective determinacy''', abbreviated '''PD''', states that for any two-player infinite game of [[perfect information]] of length [[Ω (ordinal number)|ω]] in which the players play [[natural number]]s, if the victory set (for either player, since the projective sets are closed under complementation) is projective, then one player or the other has a [[winning strategy]].
The axiom is not a theorem of [[ZFC]] (assuming ZFC is consistent), but unlike the full axiom of determinacy (AD), which contradicts the [[axiom of choice]], it is not known to be inconsistent with ZFC. PD follows from certain [[large cardinal]] axioms, such as the existence of infinitely many [[Woodin cardinal]]s.
PD implies that all projective sets are [[Lebesgue measurable]] (in fact, [[universally measurable]]) and have the [[perfect set property]] and the [[property of Baire]]. It also implies that every projective [[binary relation]] may be [[Uniformization (set theory)|uniformized]] by a projective set.
==References== * {{cite journal|last1=Martin |first1=Donald A. |author1-link=Donald A. Martin |first2=John R. |last2=Steel |author2-link=John R. Steel |date=Jan 1989 |title=A Proof of Projective Determinacy |journal=[[Journal of the American Mathematical Society]] |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=71–125 |doi=10.2307/1990913 |url=http://www.ams.org/journals/jams/1989-02-01/S0894-0347-1989-0955605-X/S0894-0347-1989-0955605-X.pdf |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430183734/http://www.ams.org/journals/jams/1989-02-01/S0894-0347-1989-0955605-X/S0894-0347-1989-0955605-X.pdf |archivedate=April 30, 2016 }} * {{cite book|last1=Moschovakis |first1=Yiannis N. |authorlink1=Yiannis N. Moschovakis |title=Descriptive set theory |date=2009 |publisher=American Mathematical Society |location=Providence, R.I. |isbn=0-8218-4813-5 |edition=2nd |url=http://www.math.ucla.edu/~ynm/lectures/dst2009/dst2009.pdf |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112111558/http://www.math.ucla.edu/~ynm/lectures/dst2009/dst2009.pdf |archivedate=2014-11-12 |df= }}
